There is no option to configure these file extensions in settings, and no prompt asking how to handle them...only where to download.

creator: Roz123

title: NS_BINDING_REDIRECT error while logging onto my college proxy login portal
content:
I have to use college proxy server to access the college network. After setting system proxy settings, we have to login at an online college proxy portal before being able to use their internet. Most of the times, the login portal is accessible via HTTP protocol, and when logging in, the form submits a POST request to their server and gets redirected to a "login_success" page, always via HTTP protocol. But every once in a while, when accessing the login portal through HTTP protocol, it redirects to the same URL but using HTTPS protocol, and when you try to login, the POST request fails with NS_BINDING_REDIRECT error, probably because it gets redirected to "login_sucess" page with HTTP protocol. No such error is raised on chromium, and I am able to login without any problem there. Any help would be much appreciated.

TLDR: NS_BINDING_REDIRECT error when logging at an online portal, since the login page uses HTTPS protocol, and successful login attempt via POST redirects to a success page using HTTP protocol.
creator: TinyTrebuchet

title: Verify integrity: "Unable to complete the coherence check"
content:
Hallo!

I run Firefox ESR 91.7.0 (64 Bit) on Debian GNU/Linux 11. When running "Verify integrity" in about:support, this is the output:

> Task: checkIntegrity + The places.sqlite database is sane + The favicons.sqlite database is sane > Task: invalidateCaches + The caches have been invalidated > Task: checkCoherence - Unable to complete the coherence check > Task: expire - The task queue was cleared by an error in another task. > Task: originFrecencyStats - The task queue was cleared by an error in another task. > Task: vacuum - The task queue was cleared by an error in another task. > Task: stats - The task queue was cleared by an error in another task. > Task: _refreshUI - The task queue was cleared by an error in another task.

It seems the integrity verification gets stuck at the coherence check. But I do not find any information what this coherence check does, if it should worry me that it cannot be completed and what I can do to fix the problem (if it is a problem). Any ideas?

title: Keeping history when updating firefox
content:
This is more about feedback rather than a question. I am unable to find a place to post feedback here, let me know if there is a better place to post this. I want to direct this to the developers, but would also welcome discussion from other users.

Background I am a user that usually keeps a lot of tabs and windows open. It is important to me that this is restored from last session when starting firefox.

When closing firefox with more windows than it will remember then the excess windows will be discarded without any warnings. Default seems to be 3 from about:config

Short term solution I think users should get a very clear message when closing firefox that it will be unable to restore the complete session later on restart. I believe this behavior is unexpected for all or most users.

Better solution The much better option here is to NOT discard session history for windows on close. ALL windows closed should be reopened without any hidden limitations inside about:config If i didn't have any very specific order in which i opened my windows then it means that the order was random, in which case firefox is discarding windows at random for later restart.

about:config lost on update? https://chantheacce71.blogspot.com/2022/03/why-does-mozilla-firefox-keeps-losing.html > When i update firefox then part of this history seems to get lost.

It's hard to recreate or to find reliable sources on this but it seems like about:config may be reset on firefox update. In which case the value is going back to 3 and all excess windows are lost even if i increased the value earlier. I recently experienced this, and it's not the first time.

If the solutions above are not used then it would be good if firefox could avoid resetting this value as the result can be disastrous.

Last time i was unable to get my window history back. i checked my sessionstore-backups and it was not there.
creator: chr_414

title: Certificate Based Authentication and SmartCard requirements
content:
Hello,

We are using Firefox on macOS to access web services that require Certificate Based Authentication. Our certificates are stored on YubiKeys PIV slots.

If we plug the token, open Firefox and access the website, it works just fine. The Certificate picker is shown and the OS ask for the PIV PIN to validate the access.

However, if we do the request when the token isn't plugged, Firefox does not ask for it, the website deny the authentication and the context is kept in cache. Requesting again the web site with the token added in between does not restart the certificate lookup and we are forced to close Firefox or move to a private window to make it works.

What is the proper way to avoid this issue? Is it a known bug? Is there a way to configure Firefox to always show the certificate picker even if no certificate are found and then reload the list of certificate based on connections events?

Thanks
creator: ygini

title: "Performing a TLS handshake..."
content:
Hi ! For a few days now I have a problem with some websites not opening, or opening very slowly with the message “performing a TLS handshake”. Other websites open without any problem. As an alternative, I use Opera, and there are no problems at all. OS is Windows 10.

I noticed for a while now that Firefox took some time to start. Then websites started to open very slowly, sometimes not at all, and then regularly the TLS handshake message was displayed. I checked for solutions, tried practically everything, but problem persists. I use the default theme, don't have extensions or add-ons I don't have any anti-virus, other than Windows Defender, integrated in Windows 10. I cleared several times the cache. History and cookies are regularly deleted when I close Firefox. I set the DNS to Google's DNS, primary 8.8.8.8, secondary 8.8.4.4. I disabled Ipv6. Renamed cert9.db, and with restart created a new file (it was cert9, and not cert8, as indicated in some posts) Started Firefox in safe mode. I performed a scan with Malwarebytes. I tried all the troubleshooting indicated on several support forums and websites. Yesterday I created a new profile. This morning I uninstalled and reinstalled Firefox. Don't know what else to do.

The profiles: There are 7 old profiles with date 12/03/2022, 19:41. Were they all set to this date by an update? One profile is displayed with yesterday's date 17/03/2022, 20:42 . This was the former active profile. I created a new profile yesterday evening, but it is displayed today with 18/03/2022, 08:12 . Maybe I did a refresh, don't remember... Another profile, “xxx.default-release”, is shown with today's date 18/03/2022, 08:41 . The newest profile, “xxx.default-release-xxxxx”, probably created with the new installation, changes its time stamp continuously and displays, when I open or close Firefox, the current hour and minutes. Is this normal or maybe an indication that something is wrong?

Anyway... any hints how tho solve this issue? Thanks in advance Michael
creator: micha.hoelt

creator: ling.noi.x

title: google no funciona
content:
Hace dos días que no me funciona el google desde firefox. Me dice que hay un problema de seguridad del mismo google. En otros navegadores sí que me funciona. Dice esto:

No se ha conectado: Posible problema de seguridad Firefox ha detectado una potencial amenaza de seguridad y no ha continuado a www.google.com porque este sitio web requiere una conexión segura. ¿Qué puede hacer al respecto? www.google.com tiene una política de seguridad llamada HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS), que significa que Firefox solo puede conectarse a él de forma segura. No puede añadir una excepción para visitar este sitio. El problema está probablemente en el sitio web, y no hay nada que pueda hacer para resolverlo. Si está en una red corporativa o utilizando un antivirus, puede ponerse en contacto con el equipo de asistencia para obtener ayuda. También puede notificar el problema al administrador del sitio web.
creator: cagicap

title: Privacy: Firefox Knows User Account Name
content: Firefox is a very private browser, and that is why I like it. But recently, when I was pairing my Android Firefox with my Mac Firefox, Firefox asked me whether I want to confirm pairing. This all worked fine, but I noticed that Firefox mentioned the home folder of the account on my mac on which it was installed to identify that Firefox instance running on my Mac. This home folder is the name of my user account, which is my actual name. So Firefox has access to and is in some sense broadcasting my actual name over the internet. I understand that this might be only viewable by me and encrypted, so not even viewable by Firefox itself let alone the public internet (and I hope my understanding is correct and this is indeed the case--correct me if I am wrong), but it was still disconcerting that "metadata" like this is floating around the internet which can easily identify someone even if he goes to great lengths for privacy.

title: Still no Autofill outside USA??
content:
I'm becoming increasingly frustrated by the lack of Address Autofill in Firefox for people outside USA. I mean physical street address, telephone, etc Every time I fill in a form online that requires phone number or street address, I have to go & open my Contacts App & locate my mobile number, or manually type everything. For a modern browser its an essential feature that is sorely lacking.

This article explains at the top that address autofill is limited to people in the US. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/automatically-fill-your-address-web-forms

For the rest of the planet, we have no autofill section in the privacy settings.

HOWEVER: I have enabled this feature using about:config to attempt to use it, using the testing section mentioned on this page: https://wiki.mozilla.org/Firefox/Features/Form_Autofill#Feature_Availability

This then lets me access the autofill settings & enter my name, address, postcode, tel, etc - but this just doesn't work on any website, I dont see any suggestions when I fill in forms. ~ or perhaps I am doing something wrong? In the `extensions.formautofill.supportedCountries` config I have US,CA,UK,GB Just adding UK didnt seem to work, so I added GB as well, but still no suggestions.

Is there any way to get this working? Why are Mozilla not supporting other countries? Is there an alternative extension I can use?

Thanks! I am using Firefox 98
creator: riquez

title: Firefox 98 options for downloads / security warnings
content:
I just updated from Firefox 96 to 98. This introduced the following problems:

  • all known file types were set to "save file" (so I had to go through the whole list and reset it back to "always ask" for like 30+ file types
  • downloading an unknown file type for the first time gets automatically set to "save file" instead of "always ask"

and the most annoying issue:

  • selecting "open with.." in the "always ask"-triggered what-to-do-dialog (e.g. to open a PDF in okular, or an ICA file with citrix) produces a warning popup "<the file> is an executable file. Executable files may contain viruses or other malicious code that could harm your computer. Use caution when opening this file. Are you sure you want to launch" (even for JPG)

I tried closing Firefox, deleting handlers.json, but this behavior did not change.

title: Discord is not properly compatible with firefox.
content:
Discord is almost compatible with the web environment, and firefox is fine for most uses.

However, the discord also has a stream function, and in this case, there are many parts that are not properly compatible.

For example, Most game cannot be captured properly for stream. If you play the game as Admin caps, more likely to not be able to capture it.

For example, It can't adjust the volume of the watching stream. If you try to mute or adjust the volume using Discord UI, it will be ignored. You need to lower and raise the volume using the media control in the context menu. Even if you watch multiple streams at the same time, you can't hear the sound properly.

title: Firefox change to file download options
content: Firefox have stopped offering the option to just OPEN a file or attachment. Files are now automatically saved to 'Downloads' or can be saved to another folder. This sudden autocratic change has caused much grief to many Firefox users judging by comments already made in numerous forums. It appears some Firefox 'brainstormers' created this change to 'benefit' users and to prevent data loss etc. Well, this user and many others strongly disagree and hope that Firefox will reconsider their decision or at least offer some alternative or option to 'just open' a file without saving it. I have, for now, installed an old Firefox version (96.0) to recover the old option menu to open or save files. However, if Firefox persist with this change, without offering a 'open only' option, I and many other users will be forced to switch to other browsers, e.g. Microsoft Edge, which do offer that option.
